header_summary:
Jonas Nick's analysis of the MuSig2 cryptographic protocol reveals its susceptibility to an attack strategy that exploits the protocol's handling of partial signatures. This vulnerability, particularly underlined in the distinction between MuSig2 and its iteration, MuSig2-IAS, emphasizes the need for a clear security framework to evaluate the implications of such attacks. The discussion sheds light on the complexity of securing cryptographic systems and suggests potential enhancements for the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal to bolster MuSig2's resilience against sophisticated threats ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/be3813bf-467d-4880-9383-2a0b0223e7e5@gmail.com/T/#ma5caeb3f9ae0465e3e60cb3b7e53cef1298983)).

Peter Todd reflects on Sjors Provoost's proposal on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List to remove the limitations associated with OP_Return outputs in the Bitcoin protocol. Provoost argues that lifting these restrictions could alleviate technical and financial inefficiencies, enhancing the blockchain's functionality without compromising security. This suggestion is part of a broader discussion aimed at optimizing the system's efficiency and versatility to support more diverse operations ([Peter Todd's insights](https://petertodd.org)).

sCrypt's discussion introduces the `SCRIPT_VERIFY_DISCOURAGE_OP_SUCCESS` rule within the Bitcoin protocol, highlighting its impact on the execution reliability of Bitcoin transactions. This standardness rule, which causes scripts containing `OP_SUCCESSx` operations to fail, plays a crucial role in maintaining the security and integrity of script execution. The conversation also explores the potential implications of betting on Bitcoin upgrades, exemplified by the `OP_CAT` activation, emphasizing the complexity and risks associated with script execution policies ([Bitcoin's GitHub repository](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/e5a00b24972461f7a181bc184dd461cedcce6161/src/policy/policy.hL126), [original article](https://scryptplatform.medium.com/betting-on-bitcoin-upgrades-a-smart-contract-wager-on-op-cat-activation-607c8f12da91)).

In the realm of block building and optimization within blockchain technology, sipa introduces the concept of transaction linearization. This approach, aiming to maximize the area under the fee-size diagram, suggests a method for achieving optimal transaction ordering within blocks. Although identifying sub-chunk-optimal linearizations presents a computational challenge, this methodology has significant implications for enhancing the average feerate achievable within a block. The discussions underscore the ongoing efforts to refine blockchain technology's efficiency and reliability ([Delving into Bitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/cluster-mempool-block-building-with-sub-chunk-granularity/1044)).

recent_posts.title: DahLIAS: Discrete Logarithm-Based Interactive Aggregate Signatures
recent_posts.summary:
- Jonas Nick discusses MuSig2's vulnerability to a specific attack strategy.
- MuSig2-IAS allows for varied messages, highlighting differences in forgery classification.
- Addressing these vulnerabilities could strengthen the protocol against sophisticated attacks.

recent_posts.title: Relax OP_RETURN standardness restrictions
recent_posts.summary:
- Sjors Provoost suggested removing OP_Return output limits to address inefficiencies.
- Multiple OP_Return outputs are needed for scenarios like SIGHASH_SINGLE transaction signing.
- Adjusting these limitations could enhance Bitcoin's functionality and security.

recent_posts.title: Betting on Bitcoin Upgrades: A Smart Contract Wager on OP_CAT Activation
recent_posts.summary:
- The `SCRIPT_VERIFY_DISCOURAGE_OP_SUCCESS` rule forces scripts with `OP_SUCCESSx` to fail in Bitcoin.
- Implementation of this rule enhances Bitcoin transaction security and script reliability.
- Discussions expand on smart contract wagers and potential risks in Bitcoin's decentralized validation system.

recent_posts.title: A simple backup scheme for wallet accounts
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion suggests enhancing cryptographic security by not generating key parts for unauthorized users.
- It proposes using varied entropy sources for key generation to improve standardization and enable hardware integration.
- Incorporating an error correction mechanism is emphasized for reliable backup integrity in disaster recovery scenarios.

recent_posts.title: Cluster mempool definitions & theory
recent_posts.summary:
- Optimizing transaction linearization in blockchain increases the unconvexified area under the fee-size diagram.
- Defining sub-chunk-optimal linearizations directly relates to enhancing average feerate within a block.
- No efficient algorithm for sub-chunk-optimal sequences exists, but a post-linearization algorithm shows promise.

today_in_history_posts.title: Trustless Segwit activation bounty protocol (aka. bribing the miners)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A proposed protocol allows pledging to a Segwit bounty, paid if activated or returned otherwise.
- Contributors set a bounty, create transactions for miner verification, and publish for potential payouts.
- If Segwit activates, miners claim the bounty; if not, contributors reclaim their funds.

today_in_history_posts.title: [RFC] Lightning payment format
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell introduces a draft for lightning payment requests on GitHub.
- The draft could be reduced by five characters; Bech32 detects three errors up to 1024 characters.
- Russell suggests using an 8-byte chanid for compact destination references, inviting feedback.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive investment focuses on asset acquisition without active management, like storing gold or cash.
- Active investment involves direct engagement, such as developing land or managing rental properties.
- The post suggests central banks could stabilize economies using inflationary currencies backed by deflationary ones like Bitcoin.
